Content.Question:
apple

895 King Aelfred, Pastoral Care “On ðaes siwenigean eagum beoð ða aepplas hale, ac ða braewas greatigað,..oððaet sio scearpnes bið gewird ðaes aepples.”

895 King Aelfred, Pastoral Care “Ðurh ðone aepl ðaes eagan mon maeg geseon.”

1299 W. de Biblesworth, “La prunele, the appel of the eye.”

1475 , Catholicon Anglicum “The Appyll of ye ee, pupilla.”

1586 T. Bowes, French Acad. “We see our owne eies shine within the apples of our neighbours eies.”

1600 G. Chapman, Iliad “The dart did undergore His eye-lid, by his eye's dear roots, & out the apple fell.”

1601 P. Holland, Hist. World “None have their eyes all of one color, for the bal or apple in the midst is ordinarily of another color than the white about.”

1705 , Philos. Trans. 1704–05 “Having carefully observ'd the Eyes of several Fishes..I found that the..Pupil or Apple of the Eye, was very flat, like those in Human Creatures.”

1753 , Chambers's Cycl. “He cut asunder the Apple of the eye in several animals.”

1827 , Blackwood's Edinb. Mag. “Dull people turn up..the apples of their eyes on beholding Prose by a Poet.”

1870 , Anthropol. Rev. “Large dark blue sparkling eye..with much white, of a bluish shade, visible under the apple.”

1912 , Lancet “The eye was also considered so as to elucidate the origin and application of such terms as bulb, apple, iris, pupil, cataract.”

1957 H. Williamson, Golden Virgin “Just you take a look at Jimmy here's eye..two circles there be, one for range and t'other for intelligence, and locked up in the apple, sir.”

2004 , People “At this time the pupil of the eye was thought to be a solid object and was known as the apple because it was spherical.”
Content.Answer: apple - More fully apple of the eye. The pupil of the eye, originally thought to be a solid, spherical body. Occasionally also: the iris and pupil, or the whole eyeball. Now historical.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

935 , Cleopatra Gloss. “Spere, aepples.”

1045 , Metrical Dialogue of Solomon & Saturn “Worpað hine deofol on domdaege, draca egeslice, bismorlice, of blacere liðran irenum aplum.”

1424 , Mandeville's Trav. “He was wont to holden a round appell of gold in his hond.”

1430 J. Lydgate, Daunce Machabree “Ȝe most forsake of golde ȝowre appil rounde Sceptre and swerde.”

1559 P. Morwyng, Treasure of Euonymus “To make ye apple of the chieck ruddy.”

1578 H. Wotton, Courtlie Controuersie “The knight kneeleth..with his naked sworde vnder his arme, the whiche beeing made of Iasper sprinkled with Uermilion spots, seemeth to be al bloudy, & hee presenteth an apple of the same stone to the Princesse.”

1601 P. Holland, Hist. World “Hold a round ball or hollow apple of glasse.”

1650 R. Heath, Clarastella “You that carried Summer in your lips..That in the Apples of your cheeks did wear A fertile Autumn now no fruit can bear?”

1705 J. S., City & Country Recreation “Shrugging up her Shoulders, to shew the tempting Apples of her white Breasts.”

1743 W. Guthrie, Trav. “The Vane on the Top of the Steeple is a Piece of fine Work..at the Extremity is a large gilded Apple or Globe.”

1781 W. Cooke, Medallic Hist. Imperial Rome “A Venus, with the Wand or Hasta pura in one Hand, and the Golden Apple or Globe in the other.”

1865 ‘Philocomus’, Love Feast “He press'd His hand upon the apples of my breast.”

1881 , N.Y. Art Interchange “Of double-faced Canton flannel, finished with fringe and floss apples.”

1956 M. Hargrove, Girl he left Behind “Andy picked up his two grenades... The apples felt strangely heavy in his hands.”

1974 , Encycl. Brit. Macropaedia “Thereafter the ‘imperial apple’ became an important emblem of the royal power invested in the monarch.”

1975 C. W. Smith, Country Music “A peasant blouse that showed the top of those lovely little apples.”

2004 , Red “Apply powder blush directly to the apple of the cheek.”
Content.Answer: apple - Any of various things resembling an apple in form or colour; spec. = pome n.1 2.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

935 , Cleopatra Gloss. “Mala punica, ða affricaniscan aeppla.”

950 , Bald's Leechbk. “Genim brembelaeppel & elehtran & pollegian, gecnua.”

1025 , Old Eng. Hexateuch: Num. “We haefdon cucumeres, þaet sind eorðaepla, & pepones & porleac & enneleac & manega oþre þingc.”

1300 , St. Brendan “Þe Applene weren ripe inouȝ, riȝt ase it heruest were.”

1324 , Gen. & Exod. “Quane here apples ripe ben, fier-isles man mai ðor-inne sen.”

1397 J. Trevisa, De Proprietatibus Rerum “Alle maner appul þat is closed in an harde skyn, rynde or schale is ycleped nux.”

1399 , Cursor Mundi “Þar-bi groues sum apell tre, Wit appuls selcut fair to se, Quen þai ar in hand, als a fise bal, To poudir wit a stink þai fal.”

1450 , Practica Phisicalia John of Burgundy “Take þe appullis of sypressus and ete hem or þe pouder of þe applys dryed.”

1555 R. Eden, Decades of Newe Worlde “Venemous apples wherwith they poyson theyr arrowes.”

1567 J. Maplet, Greene Forest “The Mandrake..beareth sayth Isidore, an Apple of sweete smell, which of some is called the Apple of the earth.”

1601 P. Holland, Hist. World “Hereof commeth the colour Puniceus (i. a light red or a bay) taking the name of the apple Punicke or Pomegranate.”

1607 E. Topsell, Hist. Foure-footed Beastes “The fruite or Apples of Palme-trees.”

1660 Bp. J. Taylor, Worthy Communicant “The other trees gave no fruit; an uselesse apple from the Oak, or little berries from the Laurel and the Myrtle.”

1704 , Voy. E.-Indies “The apples call'd pompions by the Dutch,..grow scarce anywhere else in the Indies but in the Isle of Great Java.”

1784 J. Cook, Voy. Pacific “It is remarkable for producing great quantities of that delicious fruit we called apples.”

1849 J. H. Balfour, Man. Bot. “The Custard-apples, Sweetsops, and Soursops, of the East and West Indies, are furnished by various species of Anona.”

1858 , Harper's Mag. “Then came a course of fruits grown upon the place: luscious ‘Ripley’ Pine Apples and Star Apples (the latter..when cut across, displayed the seed chambers arranged in the exact form of a star).”

1908 N. L. Britton, N. Amer. Trees “It is a much-branched small tree or shrub, reaching a height of 6 meters, and is also known as the Punic apple.”

1930 , Times Educ. Suppl. “A section of the ‘potato apple’ is like that of the tomato.”

2005 , Smithsonian “I had inadvertently cut the branch of an overhanging manzanillo tree, whose apples are poison to humans.”
Content.Answer: apple - Frequently with distinguishing word: any of various fruits (and vegetables), esp. those thought to resemble the apple (sense 1) in some way; any of the plants producing such a fruit (or vegetable).
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

950 King Aelfred, De Consol. Philos. “Se godcunda anwald gefrioðode his deorlingas under fiðra sceate, & hi scilde swa geornlice swa man deð þone aeppel on his eagan.”

1050 King Aelfred, Psalms “Geheald me, Drihten, and beorh me, swa swa man byrhð þam aeplum on his eagum mid his braewum.”

1350 , Psalter “Kepe me..as þe appel of þyn eȝe.”

1399 , Psalter “Als appel ofe eghe yheme þou me.”

1584 R. Hakluyt, Disc. Western Planting “If you touche him in the Indies, you touche the apple of his eye.”

1607 E. Sharpham, Cupids Whirligig “that shall nourish no blood but your owne, tender your reputation as the apple of her eye, & honour euen your verie footsteps.”

1693 J. Bancroft, Henry II “He can't live without you. You're the Apple of his Eye, the Joy of his Heart, the Lamp of his Life.”

1766 M. Bruce, Poems “His daughter beautiful and young..The perfect picture of her mother's youth, His age's hope, the apple of his eye.”

1816 W. Scott, Old Mortality “Poor Richard was to me as an eldest son, the apple of my eye.”

1877 , Spirit of Times “Col. Gildersleeve has lost his valuable setter dog Don, which animal was the apple of his eye.”

1884 , Harper's Mag. “He was a master of his profession, and his journal was to him as the apple of his eye.”

1930 R. Campbell, Poems “Live and die The apple, nay the onion, of his eye?”

1987 R. Mistry, Tales from Firozsha Baag “He parked his 1932 Mercedes-Benz (he called it the apple of his eye) outside A Block.”

1998 P. Jooste, Dance with Poor Man's Daughter “Errol was the apple of my grandmother's eye because he was her eldest.”
Content.Answer: apple - More fully apple of the eye. figurative and in extended use. Originally: the type of something precious. In later use chiefly the apple of a person's eye: the particular object of a person's affection or regard; a greatly cherished person or occasionally thing.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

950 , Bald's Leechbk. “Him mon on fruman þa mettas gife..swa swa beoþ aeppla, nales to swete ealles ac surmelsce, & peran & persucas.”

1000 , Metrical Charm: Nine Herbs “Wudusuraeppel, fille & finul, ealde sapan. Gewyrc ða wyrta to duste, maengc wiþ þa sapan & wiþ þaes aepples gor.”

1224 , MS Lamb. “He..bið al swa is an eppel iheoweð.”

1325 , Chron. Robert of Gloucester “As he bi huld an hey, Vpe þe hexte bowe tweye applen he sey; & þe bowes of þe on appel smite þe oþer vaste.”

1400 W. Langland, Piers Plowman “I prayed pieres to pulle adown an apple.”

1449 R. Pecock, Repressor “This tree..bringith forth soure applis.”

1533 T. Elyot, Castel of Helthe “Rough tasted appules are holsome where the stomake is weake.”

1577 N. Breton, Floorish vpon Fancie “Giue him an Apple, or a Peare, or some such chyldes rewarde.”

1653 R. Austen, Treat. Fruit-trees “Syder is usually made of such Apples as are moist sommer fruits.”

1663 J. Beale, Let. “They commonly mingle water in ye presse wth ye apples (a good quantity) whilst they grind ye apples.”

1712 R. Steele, Spectator “Venders of..apples, plumbs.”

1779 J. Abercrombie, Brit. Fruit-gardener “Apples arrive to perfection for use..from July or August, until the end of October.”

1813 H. Davy, Elements Agric. Chem. “Most of our best apples are supposed to have been introduced into Britain by a fruiterer of Henry the Eighth.”

1876 F. R. Elliot, Hand-bk. for Fruit Growers “We count the apple as the King of fruits, because it is more generally known and used than any other.”

1929 L. W. Reese, Victorian Village “With what..delight did we children hover round our elders at night, while they gilded walnuts, or rubbed apples until they were as glossy as our own cheeks.”

1952 , Times “Many thousands of tons of apples are wasted yearly.”

2006 , Weight Watchers Mag. “This handy apple corer/segmenter..will core and slice an apple into 12 even segments easily and simply.”
Content.Answer:
apple - The round firm fruit (a pome) of any of various wild and cultivated trees of the genus Malus (see sense 4a), occurring in a wide variety of forms, colours, and flavours; esp. any of numerous cultivated kinds produced throughout the temperate zones of both hemispheres, typically having crisp white flesh and green, yellow, or red skin.
This is the main current sense
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

1000 , Genesis B “Aeppel unsaelga, þone hire aer forbead drihtna drihten, deaðbeames ofet.”

1225 , Ancrene Riwle “Eue bi heold oðe for boden appel.”

1399 , Cursor Mundi “How adam brake goddis comandement of the appil.”

1450 , Bk. Knight of La Tour Landry “The delite of the apill l slow Eue.”

1499 , St. Erkenwald “Adam, oure alder, þat ete of þat appulle.”

1526 W. Bonde, Pylgrimage of Perfection “These maner of people sell paradise for an apple, with Adam and Eue.”

1618 T. Adams, Happines of Church “Was it such a sinne for Adam to eate a forbidden Apple? Yes, the greatnes is remonstrable in the euent.”

1667 J. Milton, Paradise Lost “Him by fraud I have seduc'd From his Creator..with an Apple.”

1749 J. J. Hornyold, Real Princ. Catholicks “To eat Meat that is forbidden, doth defile the Soul, as the Apple defiled Adam's.”

1829 R. Southey, All for Love “The Apple had done but little for me If Eve had not done the rest.”

1871 H. B. Stowe, My Wife & I “You see, Eva, since Adam took the apple from Eve men have obeyed women nem. con.”

1924 D. H. Lawrence, Phoenix “Since man ate the apple..the human emotions are like a wedded wife.”

1941 A. Kreymborg, Poetic Drama “In the Elizabethan era which, like the Hebraic and Christian, never recovered from the apple Eve gave Adam, woman was often a glorious strumpet.”

2006 , Daily Mail “The fear of Friday the 13th..is thought to have its origins in the Bible, as it was on a Friday when Eve took a bite from the apple.”
Content.Answer: apple - According to post-biblical Christian tradition: the fruit of the tree of knowledge of good and evil eaten by Adam and Eve in the Garden of Eden in defiance of God's commandment; the forbidden fruit. Also used allusively.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

1499 , Treat. Gardening “Yn the calendars of Ianuar' Thu sclatt treys both set & rere To graffy ther yn appyl & pere.”

1577 B. Googe, Foure Bks. Husbandry “Takyng a branche of a Beeche a foote thicke: and when they haue cutte it and bored it, they set in it the branches of the best Peare or Apple that they can geat.”

1626 F. Bacon, Sylua Syluarum “Oakes, Beeches, Chesnuts,..&c. last longer than Apples, Peares, Plums, &c.”

1653 R. Austen, Treat. Fruit-trees “Graft..all kinds of Apples together, and also on Crabstocks.”

1731 P. Miller, Gardeners Kalendar “You may also continue to prune Pears, Apples, and Plums until the middle or latter end of the next month.”

1774 W. Bartram, Trav. Georgia & Florida “Fruit Trees thrive very well here, Apples Pears, Peaches, Plumbs Nectrans, Cherries Rasberries, & Several other fine Fruit.”

1816 W. Darby, Geogr. Descr. Louisiana “The apple, though cultivated,..seems to be an exotic in southern Louisiana.”

1887 J. J. Black, Cultiv. Peach & Pear “The pear may be budded on the thorn, the mountain ash, or the apple, but the practice is not to be recommended.”

1907 , Times “A friend of mine..recently bought a tract of land in Georgia, with a view to planting apples.”

1940 E. Step, Wayside & Woodland Trees “The Wild Apple has not the pyramidal form of the Wild Pear.”

1973 , Vermont Life “In 1883 Allen planted a mixture of Northern Spy, Baldwin and Rhode Island Greening apples.”

2005 C. Tudge, Secret Life Trees “Some temperate trees (like apples and horse chestnuts) are pollinated by animals.”
Content.Answer: apple - Any tree of the genus Malus (family Rosaceae); esp. any of the numerous varieties cultivated for their fruit, probably of hybrid origin and usually classified as M. domestica, having alternate serrated leaves and white blossom appearing in the spring, followed by fruit in late summer or autumn. Cf. apple tree n.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

1668 J. Finch, Let. “He undertakes to Prove, that No Animal is generated but out of another Animal; Or some Plant Uncorrupted; as out of Oakapples, and severall prutuberancyes and Excresency's of Vegetables.”

1768 A. Tucker, Light of Nature Pursued “The fly injects her juices into the oak leaf, to raise an apple for hatching her young.”

1861 R. T. Hulme, Elements Med. Zool. “Bedeguars, commonly called ‘Soft apples’. This name is given to Galls which are covered with numerous close-set hairs or fibres.”

1869 , Eng. Mech. “Mecca galls, Dead Sea apples, Sodom apples, or mad apples..are occasionally imported from Bussarah.”

1900 , Bull. Torrey Bot. Club “The other..does not form galls or ‘apples’, but the teleutospore masses break out directly from the stem.”

1943 B. O. Dodge, Dis. & Pests of Ornamental Plants “Similar galls of a beautiful rose color develop sometimes on cranberries; they are called ‘rose apples’.”

2002 , N.Y. Rev. Bks. “The oak gall, or oak-apple, was the source of the ink in many an old master drawing that is now falling to pieces.”
Content.Answer: apple - Chiefly with distinguishing word: a gall on the stem or leaf of a plant.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

1815 , Edinb. Encycl. “The wood of France may be divided into six classes..for the fourth, fir, beech, elm, pear tree, apple, cherry tree.”

1857 E. L. Tarbuck, Encycl. Pract. Carpentry & Joinery “Pear tree is superior in toughness to apple, but the latter excels sycamore and chestnut in hardness.”

1903 R. W. Cole, “The woods used for turning are roughly divided into hard and soft... The latter include walnut, mahogany, oak, beech..and apple.”

1957 M. Hadfield, Brit. Trees “When dry apple is one of the best woods for fuel.”

1990 , Woodworker “He will use fruitwoods such as apple, plum, and, particularly, pear with its tight knit quality.”
Content.Answer: apple - The wood of any of these trees, esp. used in woodworking. Cf. apple-wood n. at compounds 1a(a).
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

1857 ‘Ducange Anglicus’, Vulgar Tongue “Apple and Pears, stairs.”

1892 , Sporting Times “The clock on the apples and pears Gave the office for us to clear.”

1909 J. R. Ware, Passing Eng. Victorian Era “Bill an' Jack's gone up apples.”

1914 C. Mackenzie, Sinister St. “I soon shoved him down the Apples-and-pears.”

1962 J. G. Bennett, Witness “One of the removal men asked him if a sofa was to go ‘up the apples’.”

2006 , Forward “I fell down the apples and landed on me bottle.”
Content.Answer: apple - In full apple(s) and pears. Stairs.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
rotten apple

1887 G. H. Devol, Forty Years Gambler on Mississippi “Those fellows are rotten apples.”

1918 F. Riesenberg, Under Sail “There's no choosing between them rotten apples aft.”

1962 R. Dougherty, Commissioner “Seen from this angle he looked what, in Bonaro's words he was,—‘a bad apple’.”

1980 L. Kennedy, Brit. Intelligence Services in Action “The original ‘rotten apple’ is believed to have been a government agent.”

2006 , Detroit News “You are the one that's going to be stuck with the bill if you pick a bad apple.”
Content.Answer: rotten apple - rotten (also bad) apple: a negative or corrupting influence on others; a troublesome or despicable person; cf. phrases 2.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

1895 S. J. Weyman, From Mem. Minister of France “I saw the apple in his throat rise and fall with the effort he made to swallow.”

1922 J. Joyce, Ulysses “He looked..up and down the quay, a big apple bulging in his neck.”

1946 C. Fry, Phoenix too Frequent “I love all the world And the movement of the apple in your throat.”

1992 , N.Y. Times Bk. Rev. “Put one hand on the apple of the hound's throat and the other at the back of his head.”
Content.Answer: apple - = Adam's apple n. 3.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

1902 , Delphos (Ohio) Daily Herald “A gang of apple knockers strolled toward Mendon.., with Charles Dewey, the famous twirler.”

1914 , Lincoln (Nebraska) Daily News “Bert is playing a great game at third base and riding the old apple with wonderful severity.”

1931 D. Runyon, Collier's “Jo-jo belts the old apple right through a high window.”

1989 R. A. Spears, NTC's Dict. Amer. Slang “Just when I raised my arms to throw to second, the damn apple slipped out of my hand.”

2004 , Daily News (N.Y.) “I'm glad Marbury is a Knick, but he sure does like to chuck that old apple, doesn't he?”
Content.Answer: apple - U.S. colloquial. A baseball. Also more fully old apple.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

1923 , Daily Mail “Colours: Peach, Apple, Apricot, Mauve, Fuchsia, Periwinkle.”

1970 , Guardian “Mini dress..coffee, apple, rose or delphinium print on green.”

1995 , Independent “Five minutes later, the same outfit again—this time in tangerine, then apple, then citrus.”

2000 , Glebe & Inner City News (Austral.) “The hottest summer colours..include the dusted pastels of violet, poppy, apple,.”
Content.Answer: apple - A shade of green resembling the colour of a green apple. Cf. apple green n. adj. at compounds 2.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

1926 , Life “No. 1711 has the smart ‘apple bowl’. A sporty looker, and a mighty friendly, comfortable pipe.”

1954 A. Dunhill, Gentle Art of Smoking “The ‘Apple’ and the ‘Prince’ are examples of smaller, lighter bowls.”

1972 M. J. Bosse, Incident at Naha “He lit a pipe, his largest shell-briar Apple.”

1994 , Daily Oklahoman (Okla. City, Okla.) “Hand-carved pipes..including..a roughneck with an apple bowl for $18.95.”

2000 D. Wright, Pipe Compan. “Apple, a classic pipe bowl shape resembling the roundness of an apple.”
Content.Answer: apple - Also with capital initial. A round, apple-shaped bowl on a tobacco pipe (also more fully apple bowl); a tobacco pipe with such a bowl.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

1928 S. J. Perelman, Judge “‘I can't say,’ replied the poor apple.”

1941 , Life Mag. “Boys do not meet with subdeb approval..are lumped together under such terms as..sad apples, meatballs,..and drips.”

1976 R. P. Davis, Pilot “That's a different department; I don't hobnob with those apples.”

2004 , Business Week “Leonard himself was a pretty tough apple.”
Content.Answer: apple - colloquial (chiefly U.S.). A person; a fellow, a guy. Usually with preceding adjective.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

1939 C. Calloway, New Cab Calloway's Cat-ologue “Apple, the big town, the main stem, Harlem.”

1953 R. Ellison, Let. “I'll write you from the apple.”

1974 G. Giddins, Village Voice (N.Y.) “Both groups are symptomatic of the flood of young musicians storming into the Apple, abandoning studio sinecures and rock bands to play difficult improvisatory music.”

2005 , Wall St. Jrnl. “Many of the city's most creative people in the 1970s (as now) were high IQ boys and girls from Smalltown who fled to the Apple.”
Content.Answer: apple - U.S. slang (originally Jazz). Usually with capital initial. With the. Originally: Harlem. Hence later: New York City. Cf. Big Apple n. 4.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

1943 J. Binning, Target Area “If everything is running smoothly ‘she's apples’.”

1952 T. A. G. Hungerford, Ridge & River “How's it going, Wally? Everything apples?”

1958 R. Stow, To Islands “She felt their faint movements of relief and surprise. ‘Well,’ said Dixon, ‘that'd be a break. That'd be apples, that would.’”

1963 R. H. Morrieson, Scarecrow “Don't cry, Pru. Yuh go and see old Len Ramsbottom and betcha everything'll be apples.”

1975 , Sydney Morning Herald “No one reckons it's ‘apples’ in the battle for Bass.”

1977 R. Beilby, Gunner “She's apples. Now you just lie back an' take it easy.”

1992 R. Puxley, Cockney Rabbit “Apples & Rice, nice. Generally shortened to the first element when describing something that is nice, e.g. ‘She's apples’. But used in full when used to describe something that isn't, e.g., ‘Oh, that's very apples and rice. I'm out of work and you're pregnant again.’”

1994 , Fast Forward “Well, she's not much of a motor, but with a spray job and a new radiator she'll be apples!”
Content.Answer: apple - slang (chiefly Australian and New Zealand). Used to indicate a state of affairs regarded as good or satisfactory (or occasionally ironic the reverse). Chiefly in she's (also it's) apples and variants: everything is all right; things will be fine (see she pron.1 2a(e)).
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

1970 , Lawton (Okla.) Constit. “Her 8-year-old boy criticized her 10-year-old daughter by calling her an ‘apple.’”

1986 P. G. Allen, Sacred Hoop “The ‘apples’, who categorically reject the Indian culture they were born to, choose one side, the white.”

1994 R. Hendrickson, Happy Trails “You ain't shit, you fucking apple.”

2001 , Adrenalin “I never saw money to do good things to Indians, it turns them into ‘Apples’—red on the outside, white in the middle.”
Content.Answer: apple - U.S. slang (derogatory). In North American Indian usage: a North American Indian regarded as espousing or adopting the values of white society or culture (see quot. 2001). Cf. Oreo n.1 2.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

1601 P. Holland, Hist. World “For all the sort of them during the Summer throughout, never rest and give over, but either they floure, or they apple, or els be readie to bring foorth fruit.”

1693 J. Evelyn, Compl. Gard'ner “To Pome or Apple, is said of the Heads of Artichokes when they grow round, and full shaped as an Apple. It is said also of Lettuce, &c.”

1712 J. Morton, Nat. Hist. Northants. “Unless the Soil has some mixture of Sand the Turnips do not apple, as they call it: that is, do not bottom well.”

1750 W. Ellis, Mod. Husbandman “The Turneps grew 'till Christmas or longer, and appled well in gravelly or stony Grounds, because their Roots can't here enter so deep.”

1798 C. Marshall, Introd. Knowl. & Pract. Gardening “The cabbage turnep is of two kinds; one apples above ground, and the other in it.”

1854 A. E. Baker, Gloss. Northants. Words “Apple, to bottom at the roots. Turnips apple well, when the roots well, and assume a bulbous form.”

1895 P. H. Emerson, Birds, Beasts, & Fishes Norfolk Broadland “The fine-leaved turnips that have escaped the fly, but have still to ‘apple’.”

1923 E. Gepp, Essex Dial. Dict. “Potatoes and onions are said to apple when they develop properly. A dialect use.”

1948 M. Carbery, Herts. Heritage “Me taters be n't applin' like they ed ough'ter.”

1995 J. M. Sims-Kimbrey, Wodds & Doggerybaw: Lincs. Dial. Dict. “Them blubs (bulbs) what we put awaay int' spring's gone an' appled nicely.”
Content.Answer:
apple - intransitive. Of vegetables, flower buds, and esp. (in later use) root crops: to swell into a globular shape; to become shaped like an apple.
This is the main current sense
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

1799 A. Young, Gen. View Agric. County Lincoln “The poor people supply themselves with very good fuel by gathering the fir-apples and rotten wood; you will sometimes see twenty children in my plantations appleing, as they call it.”

1995 J. M. Sims-Kimbrey, Wodds & Doggerybaw: Lincs. Dial. Dict. “Going out appling is going out into the woods to collect fir cones for burning.”
Content.Answer: apple - intransitive. To gather fir cones (see fir-apple n. at fir n. compounds 2). rare.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

895 King Aelfred, Pastoral Care “On ðaes siwenigean eagum beoð ða aepplas hale, ac ða braewas greatigað,..oððaet sio scearpnes bið gewird ðaes aepples.”

895 King Aelfred, Pastoral Care “Ðurh ðone aepl ðaes eagan mon maeg geseon.”

1299 W. de Biblesworth, “La prunele, the appel of the eye.”

1475 , Catholicon Anglicum “The Appyll of ye ee, pupilla.”

1586 T. Bowes, French Acad. “We see our owne eies shine within the apples of our neighbours eies.”

1600 G. Chapman, Iliad “The dart did undergore His eye-lid, by his eye's dear roots, & out the apple fell.”

1601 P. Holland, Hist. World “None have their eyes all of one color, for the bal or apple in the midst is ordinarily of another color than the white about.”

1705 , Philos. Trans. 1704–05 “Having carefully observ'd the Eyes of several Fishes..I found that the..Pupil or Apple of the Eye, was very flat, like those in Human Creatures.”

1753 , Chambers's Cycl. “He cut asunder the Apple of the eye in several animals.”

1827 , Blackwood's Edinb. Mag. “Dull people turn up..the apples of their eyes on beholding Prose by a Poet.”

1870 , Anthropol. Rev. “Large dark blue sparkling eye..with much white, of a bluish shade, visible under the apple.”

1912 , Lancet “The eye was also considered so as to elucidate the origin and application of such terms as bulb, apple, iris, pupil, cataract.”

1957 H. Williamson, Golden Virgin “Just you take a look at Jimmy here's eye..two circles there be, one for range and t'other for intelligence, and locked up in the apple, sir.”

2004 , People “At this time the pupil of the eye was thought to be a solid object and was known as the apple because it was spherical.”
Content.Answer: apple - More fully apple of the eye. The pupil of the eye, originally thought to be a solid, spherical body. Occasionally also: the iris and pupil, or the whole eyeball. Now historical.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

935 , Cleopatra Gloss. “Spere, aepples.”

1045 , Metrical Dialogue of Solomon & Saturn “Worpað hine deofol on domdaege, draca egeslice, bismorlice, of blacere liðran irenum aplum.”

1424 , Mandeville's Trav. “He was wont to holden a round appell of gold in his hond.”

1430 J. Lydgate, Daunce Machabree “Ȝe most forsake of golde ȝowre appil rounde Sceptre and swerde.”

1559 P. Morwyng, Treasure of Euonymus “To make ye apple of the chieck ruddy.”

1578 H. Wotton, Courtlie Controuersie “The knight kneeleth..with his naked sworde vnder his arme, the whiche beeing made of Iasper sprinkled with Uermilion spots, seemeth to be al bloudy, & hee presenteth an apple of the same stone to the Princesse.”

1601 P. Holland, Hist. World “Hold a round ball or hollow apple of glasse.”

1650 R. Heath, Clarastella “You that carried Summer in your lips..That in the Apples of your cheeks did wear A fertile Autumn now no fruit can bear?”

1705 J. S., City & Country Recreation “Shrugging up her Shoulders, to shew the tempting Apples of her white Breasts.”

1743 W. Guthrie, Trav. “The Vane on the Top of the Steeple is a Piece of fine Work..at the Extremity is a large gilded Apple or Globe.”

1781 W. Cooke, Medallic Hist. Imperial Rome “A Venus, with the Wand or Hasta pura in one Hand, and the Golden Apple or Globe in the other.”

1865 ‘Philocomus’, Love Feast “He press'd His hand upon the apples of my breast.”

1881 , N.Y. Art Interchange “Of double-faced Canton flannel, finished with fringe and floss apples.”

1956 M. Hargrove, Girl he left Behind “Andy picked up his two grenades... The apples felt strangely heavy in his hands.”

1974 , Encycl. Brit. Macropaedia “Thereafter the ‘imperial apple’ became an important emblem of the royal power invested in the monarch.”

1975 C. W. Smith, Country Music “A peasant blouse that showed the top of those lovely little apples.”

2004 , Red “Apply powder blush directly to the apple of the cheek.”
Content.Answer: apple - Any of various things resembling an apple in form or colour; spec. = pome n.1 2.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

935 , Cleopatra Gloss. “Mala punica, ða affricaniscan aeppla.”

950 , Bald's Leechbk. “Genim brembelaeppel & elehtran & pollegian, gecnua.”

1025 , Old Eng. Hexateuch: Num. “We haefdon cucumeres, þaet sind eorðaepla, & pepones & porleac & enneleac & manega oþre þingc.”

1300 , St. Brendan “Þe Applene weren ripe inouȝ, riȝt ase it heruest were.”

1324 , Gen. & Exod. “Quane here apples ripe ben, fier-isles man mai ðor-inne sen.”

1397 J. Trevisa, De Proprietatibus Rerum “Alle maner appul þat is closed in an harde skyn, rynde or schale is ycleped nux.”

1399 , Cursor Mundi “Þar-bi groues sum apell tre, Wit appuls selcut fair to se, Quen þai ar in hand, als a fise bal, To poudir wit a stink þai fal.”

1450 , Practica Phisicalia John of Burgundy “Take þe appullis of sypressus and ete hem or þe pouder of þe applys dryed.”

1555 R. Eden, Decades of Newe Worlde “Venemous apples wherwith they poyson theyr arrowes.”

1567 J. Maplet, Greene Forest “The Mandrake..beareth sayth Isidore, an Apple of sweete smell, which of some is called the Apple of the earth.”

1601 P. Holland, Hist. World “Hereof commeth the colour Puniceus (i. a light red or a bay) taking the name of the apple Punicke or Pomegranate.”

1607 E. Topsell, Hist. Foure-footed Beastes “The fruite or Apples of Palme-trees.”

1660 Bp. J. Taylor, Worthy Communicant “The other trees gave no fruit; an uselesse apple from the Oak, or little berries from the Laurel and the Myrtle.”

1704 , Voy. E.-Indies “The apples call'd pompions by the Dutch,..grow scarce anywhere else in the Indies but in the Isle of Great Java.”

1784 J. Cook, Voy. Pacific “It is remarkable for producing great quantities of that delicious fruit we called apples.”

1849 J. H. Balfour, Man. Bot. “The Custard-apples, Sweetsops, and Soursops, of the East and West Indies, are furnished by various species of Anona.”

1858 , Harper's Mag. “Then came a course of fruits grown upon the place: luscious ‘Ripley’ Pine Apples and Star Apples (the latter..when cut across, displayed the seed chambers arranged in the exact form of a star).”

1908 N. L. Britton, N. Amer. Trees “It is a much-branched small tree or shrub, reaching a height of 6 meters, and is also known as the Punic apple.”

1930 , Times Educ. Suppl. “A section of the ‘potato apple’ is like that of the tomato.”

2005 , Smithsonian “I had inadvertently cut the branch of an overhanging manzanillo tree, whose apples are poison to humans.”
Content.Answer: apple - Frequently with distinguishing word: any of various fruits (and vegetables), esp. those thought to resemble the apple (sense 1) in some way; any of the plants producing such a fruit (or vegetable).
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

950 King Aelfred, De Consol. Philos. “Se godcunda anwald gefrioðode his deorlingas under fiðra sceate, & hi scilde swa geornlice swa man deð þone aeppel on his eagan.”

1050 King Aelfred, Psalms “Geheald me, Drihten, and beorh me, swa swa man byrhð þam aeplum on his eagum mid his braewum.”

1350 , Psalter “Kepe me..as þe appel of þyn eȝe.”

1399 , Psalter “Als appel ofe eghe yheme þou me.”

1584 R. Hakluyt, Disc. Western Planting “If you touche him in the Indies, you touche the apple of his eye.”

1607 E. Sharpham, Cupids Whirligig “that shall nourish no blood but your owne, tender your reputation as the apple of her eye, & honour euen your verie footsteps.”

1693 J. Bancroft, Henry II “He can't live without you. You're the Apple of his Eye, the Joy of his Heart, the Lamp of his Life.”

1766 M. Bruce, Poems “His daughter beautiful and young..The perfect picture of her mother's youth, His age's hope, the apple of his eye.”

1816 W. Scott, Old Mortality “Poor Richard was to me as an eldest son, the apple of my eye.”

1877 , Spirit of Times “Col. Gildersleeve has lost his valuable setter dog Don, which animal was the apple of his eye.”

1884 , Harper's Mag. “He was a master of his profession, and his journal was to him as the apple of his eye.”

1930 R. Campbell, Poems “Live and die The apple, nay the onion, of his eye?”

1987 R. Mistry, Tales from Firozsha Baag “He parked his 1932 Mercedes-Benz (he called it the apple of his eye) outside A Block.”

1998 P. Jooste, Dance with Poor Man's Daughter “Errol was the apple of my grandmother's eye because he was her eldest.”
Content.Answer: apple - More fully apple of the eye. figurative and in extended use. Originally: the type of something precious. In later use chiefly the apple of a person's eye: the particular object of a person's affection or regard; a greatly cherished person or occasionally thing.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

950 , Bald's Leechbk. “Him mon on fruman þa mettas gife..swa swa beoþ aeppla, nales to swete ealles ac surmelsce, & peran & persucas.”

1000 , Metrical Charm: Nine Herbs “Wudusuraeppel, fille & finul, ealde sapan. Gewyrc ða wyrta to duste, maengc wiþ þa sapan & wiþ þaes aepples gor.”

1224 , MS Lamb. “He..bið al swa is an eppel iheoweð.”

1325 , Chron. Robert of Gloucester “As he bi huld an hey, Vpe þe hexte bowe tweye applen he sey; & þe bowes of þe on appel smite þe oþer vaste.”

1400 W. Langland, Piers Plowman “I prayed pieres to pulle adown an apple.”

1449 R. Pecock, Repressor “This tree..bringith forth soure applis.”

1533 T. Elyot, Castel of Helthe “Rough tasted appules are holsome where the stomake is weake.”

1577 N. Breton, Floorish vpon Fancie “Giue him an Apple, or a Peare, or some such chyldes rewarde.”

1653 R. Austen, Treat. Fruit-trees “Syder is usually made of such Apples as are moist sommer fruits.”

1663 J. Beale, Let. “They commonly mingle water in ye presse wth ye apples (a good quantity) whilst they grind ye apples.”

1712 R. Steele, Spectator “Venders of..apples, plumbs.”

1779 J. Abercrombie, Brit. Fruit-gardener “Apples arrive to perfection for use..from July or August, until the end of October.”

1813 H. Davy, Elements Agric. Chem. “Most of our best apples are supposed to have been introduced into Britain by a fruiterer of Henry the Eighth.”

1876 F. R. Elliot, Hand-bk. for Fruit Growers “We count the apple as the King of fruits, because it is more generally known and used than any other.”

1929 L. W. Reese, Victorian Village “With what..delight did we children hover round our elders at night, while they gilded walnuts, or rubbed apples until they were as glossy as our own cheeks.”

1952 , Times “Many thousands of tons of apples are wasted yearly.”

2006 , Weight Watchers Mag. “This handy apple corer/segmenter..will core and slice an apple into 12 even segments easily and simply.”
Content.Answer:
apple - The round firm fruit (a pome) of any of various wild and cultivated trees of the genus Malus (see sense 4a), occurring in a wide variety of forms, colours, and flavours; esp. any of numerous cultivated kinds produced throughout the temperate zones of both hemispheres, typically having crisp white flesh and green, yellow, or red skin.
This is the main current sense
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

1000 , Genesis B “Aeppel unsaelga, þone hire aer forbead drihtna drihten, deaðbeames ofet.”

1225 , Ancrene Riwle “Eue bi heold oðe for boden appel.”

1399 , Cursor Mundi “How adam brake goddis comandement of the appil.”

1450 , Bk. Knight of La Tour Landry “The delite of the apill l slow Eue.”

1499 , St. Erkenwald “Adam, oure alder, þat ete of þat appulle.”

1526 W. Bonde, Pylgrimage of Perfection “These maner of people sell paradise for an apple, with Adam and Eue.”

1618 T. Adams, Happines of Church “Was it such a sinne for Adam to eate a forbidden Apple? Yes, the greatnes is remonstrable in the euent.”

1667 J. Milton, Paradise Lost “Him by fraud I have seduc'd From his Creator..with an Apple.”

1749 J. J. Hornyold, Real Princ. Catholicks “To eat Meat that is forbidden, doth defile the Soul, as the Apple defiled Adam's.”

1829 R. Southey, All for Love “The Apple had done but little for me If Eve had not done the rest.”

1871 H. B. Stowe, My Wife & I “You see, Eva, since Adam took the apple from Eve men have obeyed women nem. con.”

1924 D. H. Lawrence, Phoenix “Since man ate the apple..the human emotions are like a wedded wife.”

1941 A. Kreymborg, Poetic Drama “In the Elizabethan era which, like the Hebraic and Christian, never recovered from the apple Eve gave Adam, woman was often a glorious strumpet.”

2006 , Daily Mail “The fear of Friday the 13th..is thought to have its origins in the Bible, as it was on a Friday when Eve took a bite from the apple.”
Content.Answer: apple - According to post-biblical Christian tradition: the fruit of the tree of knowledge of good and evil eaten by Adam and Eve in the Garden of Eden in defiance of God's commandment; the forbidden fruit. Also used allusively.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

1499 , Treat. Gardening “Yn the calendars of Ianuar' Thu sclatt treys both set & rere To graffy ther yn appyl & pere.”

1577 B. Googe, Foure Bks. Husbandry “Takyng a branche of a Beeche a foote thicke: and when they haue cutte it and bored it, they set in it the branches of the best Peare or Apple that they can geat.”

1626 F. Bacon, Sylua Syluarum “Oakes, Beeches, Chesnuts,..&c. last longer than Apples, Peares, Plums, &c.”

1653 R. Austen, Treat. Fruit-trees “Graft..all kinds of Apples together, and also on Crabstocks.”

1731 P. Miller, Gardeners Kalendar “You may also continue to prune Pears, Apples, and Plums until the middle or latter end of the next month.”

1774 W. Bartram, Trav. Georgia & Florida “Fruit Trees thrive very well here, Apples Pears, Peaches, Plumbs Nectrans, Cherries Rasberries, & Several other fine Fruit.”

1816 W. Darby, Geogr. Descr. Louisiana “The apple, though cultivated,..seems to be an exotic in southern Louisiana.”

1887 J. J. Black, Cultiv. Peach & Pear “The pear may be budded on the thorn, the mountain ash, or the apple, but the practice is not to be recommended.”

1907 , Times “A friend of mine..recently bought a tract of land in Georgia, with a view to planting apples.”

1940 E. Step, Wayside & Woodland Trees “The Wild Apple has not the pyramidal form of the Wild Pear.”

1973 , Vermont Life “In 1883 Allen planted a mixture of Northern Spy, Baldwin and Rhode Island Greening apples.”

2005 C. Tudge, Secret Life Trees “Some temperate trees (like apples and horse chestnuts) are pollinated by animals.”
Content.Answer: apple - Any tree of the genus Malus (family Rosaceae); esp. any of the numerous varieties cultivated for their fruit, probably of hybrid origin and usually classified as M. domestica, having alternate serrated leaves and white blossom appearing in the spring, followed by fruit in late summer or autumn. Cf. apple tree n.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

1668 J. Finch, Let. “He undertakes to Prove, that No Animal is generated but out of another Animal; Or some Plant Uncorrupted; as out of Oakapples, and severall prutuberancyes and Excresency's of Vegetables.”

1768 A. Tucker, Light of Nature Pursued “The fly injects her juices into the oak leaf, to raise an apple for hatching her young.”

1861 R. T. Hulme, Elements Med. Zool. “Bedeguars, commonly called ‘Soft apples’. This name is given to Galls which are covered with numerous close-set hairs or fibres.”

1869 , Eng. Mech. “Mecca galls, Dead Sea apples, Sodom apples, or mad apples..are occasionally imported from Bussarah.”

1900 , Bull. Torrey Bot. Club “The other..does not form galls or ‘apples’, but the teleutospore masses break out directly from the stem.”

1943 B. O. Dodge, Dis. & Pests of Ornamental Plants “Similar galls of a beautiful rose color develop sometimes on cranberries; they are called ‘rose apples’.”

2002 , N.Y. Rev. Bks. “The oak gall, or oak-apple, was the source of the ink in many an old master drawing that is now falling to pieces.”
Content.Answer: apple - Chiefly with distinguishing word: a gall on the stem or leaf of a plant.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

1815 , Edinb. Encycl. “The wood of France may be divided into six classes..for the fourth, fir, beech, elm, pear tree, apple, cherry tree.”

1857 E. L. Tarbuck, Encycl. Pract. Carpentry & Joinery “Pear tree is superior in toughness to apple, but the latter excels sycamore and chestnut in hardness.”

1903 R. W. Cole, “The woods used for turning are roughly divided into hard and soft... The latter include walnut, mahogany, oak, beech..and apple.”

1957 M. Hadfield, Brit. Trees “When dry apple is one of the best woods for fuel.”

1990 , Woodworker “He will use fruitwoods such as apple, plum, and, particularly, pear with its tight knit quality.”
Content.Answer: apple - The wood of any of these trees, esp. used in woodworking. Cf. apple-wood n. at compounds 1a(a).
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

1857 ‘Ducange Anglicus’, Vulgar Tongue “Apple and Pears, stairs.”

1892 , Sporting Times “The clock on the apples and pears Gave the office for us to clear.”

1909 J. R. Ware, Passing Eng. Victorian Era “Bill an' Jack's gone up apples.”

1914 C. Mackenzie, Sinister St. “I soon shoved him down the Apples-and-pears.”

1962 J. G. Bennett, Witness “One of the removal men asked him if a sofa was to go ‘up the apples’.”

2006 , Forward “I fell down the apples and landed on me bottle.”
Content.Answer: apple - In full apple(s) and pears. Stairs.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
rotten apple

1887 G. H. Devol, Forty Years Gambler on Mississippi “Those fellows are rotten apples.”

1918 F. Riesenberg, Under Sail “There's no choosing between them rotten apples aft.”

1962 R. Dougherty, Commissioner “Seen from this angle he looked what, in Bonaro's words he was,—‘a bad apple’.”

1980 L. Kennedy, Brit. Intelligence Services in Action “The original ‘rotten apple’ is believed to have been a government agent.”

2006 , Detroit News “You are the one that's going to be stuck with the bill if you pick a bad apple.”
Content.Answer: rotten apple - rotten (also bad) apple: a negative or corrupting influence on others; a troublesome or despicable person; cf. phrases 2.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

1895 S. J. Weyman, From Mem. Minister of France “I saw the apple in his throat rise and fall with the effort he made to swallow.”

1922 J. Joyce, Ulysses “He looked..up and down the quay, a big apple bulging in his neck.”

1946 C. Fry, Phoenix too Frequent “I love all the world And the movement of the apple in your throat.”

1992 , N.Y. Times Bk. Rev. “Put one hand on the apple of the hound's throat and the other at the back of his head.”
Content.Answer: apple - = Adam's apple n. 3.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

1902 , Delphos (Ohio) Daily Herald “A gang of apple knockers strolled toward Mendon.., with Charles Dewey, the famous twirler.”

1914 , Lincoln (Nebraska) Daily News “Bert is playing a great game at third base and riding the old apple with wonderful severity.”

1931 D. Runyon, Collier's “Jo-jo belts the old apple right through a high window.”

1989 R. A. Spears, NTC's Dict. Amer. Slang “Just when I raised my arms to throw to second, the damn apple slipped out of my hand.”

2004 , Daily News (N.Y.) “I'm glad Marbury is a Knick, but he sure does like to chuck that old apple, doesn't he?”
Content.Answer: apple - U.S. colloquial. A baseball. Also more fully old apple.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

1923 , Daily Mail “Colours: Peach, Apple, Apricot, Mauve, Fuchsia, Periwinkle.”

1970 , Guardian “Mini dress..coffee, apple, rose or delphinium print on green.”

1995 , Independent “Five minutes later, the same outfit again—this time in tangerine, then apple, then citrus.”

2000 , Glebe & Inner City News (Austral.) “The hottest summer colours..include the dusted pastels of violet, poppy, apple,.”
Content.Answer: apple - A shade of green resembling the colour of a green apple. Cf. apple green n. adj. at compounds 2.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

1926 , Life “No. 1711 has the smart ‘apple bowl’. A sporty looker, and a mighty friendly, comfortable pipe.”

1954 A. Dunhill, Gentle Art of Smoking “The ‘Apple’ and the ‘Prince’ are examples of smaller, lighter bowls.”

1972 M. J. Bosse, Incident at Naha “He lit a pipe, his largest shell-briar Apple.”

1994 , Daily Oklahoman (Okla. City, Okla.) “Hand-carved pipes..including..a roughneck with an apple bowl for $18.95.”

2000 D. Wright, Pipe Compan. “Apple, a classic pipe bowl shape resembling the roundness of an apple.”
Content.Answer: apple - Also with capital initial. A round, apple-shaped bowl on a tobacco pipe (also more fully apple bowl); a tobacco pipe with such a bowl.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

1928 S. J. Perelman, Judge “‘I can't say,’ replied the poor apple.”

1941 , Life Mag. “Boys do not meet with subdeb approval..are lumped together under such terms as..sad apples, meatballs,..and drips.”

1976 R. P. Davis, Pilot “That's a different department; I don't hobnob with those apples.”

2004 , Business Week “Leonard himself was a pretty tough apple.”
Content.Answer: apple - colloquial (chiefly U.S.). A person; a fellow, a guy. Usually with preceding adjective.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

1939 C. Calloway, New Cab Calloway's Cat-ologue “Apple, the big town, the main stem, Harlem.”

1953 R. Ellison, Let. “I'll write you from the apple.”

1974 G. Giddins, Village Voice (N.Y.) “Both groups are symptomatic of the flood of young musicians storming into the Apple, abandoning studio sinecures and rock bands to play difficult improvisatory music.”

2005 , Wall St. Jrnl. “Many of the city's most creative people in the 1970s (as now) were high IQ boys and girls from Smalltown who fled to the Apple.”
Content.Answer: apple - U.S. slang (originally Jazz). Usually with capital initial. With the. Originally: Harlem. Hence later: New York City. Cf. Big Apple n. 4.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

1943 J. Binning, Target Area “If everything is running smoothly ‘she's apples’.”

1952 T. A. G. Hungerford, Ridge & River “How's it going, Wally? Everything apples?”

1958 R. Stow, To Islands “She felt their faint movements of relief and surprise. ‘Well,’ said Dixon, ‘that'd be a break. That'd be apples, that would.’”

1963 R. H. Morrieson, Scarecrow “Don't cry, Pru. Yuh go and see old Len Ramsbottom and betcha everything'll be apples.”

1975 , Sydney Morning Herald “No one reckons it's ‘apples’ in the battle for Bass.”

1977 R. Beilby, Gunner “She's apples. Now you just lie back an' take it easy.”

1992 R. Puxley, Cockney Rabbit “Apples & Rice, nice. Generally shortened to the first element when describing something that is nice, e.g. ‘She's apples’. But used in full when used to describe something that isn't, e.g., ‘Oh, that's very apples and rice. I'm out of work and you're pregnant again.’”

1994 , Fast Forward “Well, she's not much of a motor, but with a spray job and a new radiator she'll be apples!”
Content.Answer: apple - slang (chiefly Australian and New Zealand). Used to indicate a state of affairs regarded as good or satisfactory (or occasionally ironic the reverse). Chiefly in she's (also it's) apples and variants: everything is all right; things will be fine (see she pron.1 2a(e)).
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

1970 , Lawton (Okla.) Constit. “Her 8-year-old boy criticized her 10-year-old daughter by calling her an ‘apple.’”

1986 P. G. Allen, Sacred Hoop “The ‘apples’, who categorically reject the Indian culture they were born to, choose one side, the white.”

1994 R. Hendrickson, Happy Trails “You ain't shit, you fucking apple.”

2001 , Adrenalin “I never saw money to do good things to Indians, it turns them into ‘Apples’—red on the outside, white in the middle.”
Content.Answer: apple - U.S. slang (derogatory). In North American Indian usage: a North American Indian regarded as espousing or adopting the values of white society or culture (see quot. 2001). Cf. Oreo n.1 2.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

1601 P. Holland, Hist. World “For all the sort of them during the Summer throughout, never rest and give over, but either they floure, or they apple, or els be readie to bring foorth fruit.”

1693 J. Evelyn, Compl. Gard'ner “To Pome or Apple, is said of the Heads of Artichokes when they grow round, and full shaped as an Apple. It is said also of Lettuce, &c.”

1712 J. Morton, Nat. Hist. Northants. “Unless the Soil has some mixture of Sand the Turnips do not apple, as they call it: that is, do not bottom well.”

1750 W. Ellis, Mod. Husbandman “The Turneps grew 'till Christmas or longer, and appled well in gravelly or stony Grounds, because their Roots can't here enter so deep.”

1798 C. Marshall, Introd. Knowl. & Pract. Gardening “The cabbage turnep is of two kinds; one apples above ground, and the other in it.”

1854 A. E. Baker, Gloss. Northants. Words “Apple, to bottom at the roots. Turnips apple well, when the roots well, and assume a bulbous form.”

1895 P. H. Emerson, Birds, Beasts, & Fishes Norfolk Broadland “The fine-leaved turnips that have escaped the fly, but have still to ‘apple’.”

1923 E. Gepp, Essex Dial. Dict. “Potatoes and onions are said to apple when they develop properly. A dialect use.”

1948 M. Carbery, Herts. Heritage “Me taters be n't applin' like they ed ough'ter.”

1995 J. M. Sims-Kimbrey, Wodds & Doggerybaw: Lincs. Dial. Dict. “Them blubs (bulbs) what we put awaay int' spring's gone an' appled nicely.”
Content.Answer:
apple - intransitive. Of vegetables, flower buds, and esp. (in later use) root crops: to swell into a globular shape; to become shaped like an apple.
This is the main current sense
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary

Content.Question:
apple

1799 A. Young, Gen. View Agric. County Lincoln “The poor people supply themselves with very good fuel by gathering the fir-apples and rotten wood; you will sometimes see twenty children in my plantations appleing, as they call it.”

1995 J. M. Sims-Kimbrey, Wodds & Doggerybaw: Lincs. Dial. Dict. “Going out appling is going out into the woods to collect fir cones for burning.”
Content.Answer: apple - intransitive. To gather fir cones (see fir-apple n. at fir n. compounds 2). rare.
Content.SuperMemoReference: <H5 dir=ltr align=left><Font size="1" style="color: transparent"> SuperMemo Reference:</font><br><FONT class=reference>Title:"My Test Quote" <br>Source: Oxford English Dictionary
